## Introduction

The [Binomial distribution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Binomial_distribution) is a discrete probability distribution that models count data - the number of successes in a sequence of iid [Bernoulli trials](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bernoulli_trial).

The [**Negative** Binomial distribution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negative_binomial_distribution) is similar, except that it models the number of **failures**.
The parametrisation used by R can be found [here](https://stat.ethz.ch/R-manual/R-devel/library/stats/html/NegBinomial.html). It follows from that and the exercise requirements that the `size` parameter of the `rnbinom()` function is `1/dispersion`

## The code

```{r}
# stats::dnbinom(x, size, prob, mu, log = FALSE)
# stats::pnbinom(q, size, prob, mu, lower.tail = TRUE, log.p = FALSE)
# stats::qnbinom(p, size, prob, mu, lower.tail = TRUE, log.p = FALSE)
# stats::rnbinom(n, size, prob, mu)

set.seed(12)

n = 100
mu = 10
dispersion = 2 # for the parametrisation where: variance = mu + mu**2 * dispersion

s <- rnbinom(n=100, size=1/dispersion, mu=10)  # size	target for number of successful trials, or dispersion parameter (the shape parameter of the gamma mixing distribution). Must be strictly positive, need not be integer.

hist(s)

mean = mean(s)
variance = mu + mu**2 * dispersion
```

## Comments

The steps done were:
- use a seed for random generators (for repeatability),
- defining parameters like sample size and similar,
- using a R function for sampling,
- and plotting a histogram.

The mean is `r mean` and the variance is `r variance`.
